zeros.name: The Gateway Zero
zeros.description: Found by Riemann in 1859. It confirms the Zeta function's link to the distribution of primes.

zeros.name: The Spacing Benchmark
zeros.description: Its distance from the first zero (~6.89) began the study of 'spectral gaps' in number theory.

zeros.name: The Stability Zero
zeros.description: Part of the original set that suggested all non-trivial zeros lie on the Critical Line (Re=1/2).

zeros.name: The Chaos Indicator
zeros.description: Exhibits the irregular, 'random matrix' behavior typical of complex quantum systems.

zeros.name: The Near Twin
zeros.description: Part of an unusually tight cluster, demonstrating that zeros do not appear at regular intervals.

zeros.name: Hardyâ€™s Milestone
zeros.description: Confirmed by G.H. Hardy in 1914, proving infinitely many zeros exist on the critical line.

zeros.name: The Pre-Computer Limit
zeros.description: Marks the boundary of what 19th-century mathematicians could verify through manual calculation.

zeros.name: The Repulsion Effect
zeros.description: An example of 'level repulsion,' where zeros rarely get too close, similar to energy levels in atoms.

zeros.name: The Prime Regulator
zeros.description: Higher zeros like this one 'fine-tune' the error term in the Prime Number Theorem.

zeros.name: The Gram Point Link
zeros.description: Calculated by J.P. Gram (1903), who developed the 'Gram Points' used to predict zero locations.
